column5: There are complex potential trade-offs here. Frictions can prevent exports but they also prevent imports with an ambiguous net effect.
column9: The outcome depends on a number of characteristics such as the size of the economy. Result my hold for small ones but maybe not large ones.

column5: Though significant is a bit of a vague word.
column9: This is one of Peter Neary’s great contributions to Economics, particularly exploring various channels through which it can happen. RIP.
Although appropriate policies can be used to counter the impact.
The impact on other sectors depends on the quality of economic and political institutions and on policy response to the boom.

column5: Some cross-border frictions are usual.  The almost frictionless situation in the EU is the exception -- Brexit displays the result.
column9: Due not only to sectoral competition for labour, but also to the way natural resources tend to attract venal politicians.

column5: An example can always be constructed that confirms the statement - the question is whether it generalizes to very generic settings
column9: It all depends whether or not the other sectors can adjust smoothly to the rise in factor prices driven by the boom in some sectors.
It very much depends on the economic policy response: see Norway as a counter-example to the well-known "curse of raw materials"...
Hinges on economic and political structure (resource curse can operate via politics). Norway may not be hit, even though Nigeria may be.

column5: "Significant" is in the eye of the beholder, but literature has quantified multiple relevant channels
column9: It seems to depend on the country's circumstances, and especially on the policies adopted in response.
Manufacturing firms can benefit from a resource boom if they can provide equipment servicing resource industry. Norway provides an example
